aws::graph::propositions: # Hydraulic System Post-Test Examination Details
Hydraulic systems were visually examined for evidence of leaks after lower hydraulic system functional tests.
No leaks were found in the hydraulic systems.
Nitrogen pressure was lost from the yaw load compensator accumulator when a gauge was connected.
The nitrogen pressure in the accumulator measured about 7 bars.
Normal accumulator charge is about 15 bars.
The accumulator was re-pressurized with additional nitrogen to 15 bars.
The accumulator held the 15 bars of pressure.
The accumulator holding pressure was consistent with no significant leakage of nitrogen.
The hydraulic mule was powered on during testing.
The gauge attached to the accumulator measured about 30 bars of pressure when hydraulic mule was powered on.
The 30 bars of pressure was consistent with hydraulic pressure applied to the lower hydraulic circuit by the hydraulic mule.
The hydraulic mule was powered off after testing.
The hydraulic filter clogging indicator remained in the "in" position.
The "in" position of the hydraulic filter clogging indicator was consistent with the hydraulic filter not being clogged.
The hydraulic filter element was removed and examined for debris.
No debris was found on the filter element.
Very fine debris was observed in the bottom of the filter bowl.
The hydraulic pump drive belt from the lower hydraulic circuit was removed.
The belt removal was done to verify engagement of the spline coupling.
The spline coupling connects the drive pulley to the hydraulic pump.
Spline coupling engagement was confirmed.
The tail rotor pitch change links were disconnected from the tail rotor blades.
The full range of pedal movement was verified.
Corresponding movements of the pitch change were verified.
The AS350B3 with dual hydraulic system checklist requires a hydraulic system check during helicopter run up.
The Servo Distributors Seizure Check requires depressing the SERVO TEST or SERVO TST button.
When SERVO TEST or SERVO TST is depressed, the SERVO light illuminates.
The Yaw Servo Hydraulic Check requires turning the yaw servo hydraulic switch on the collective grip to OFF.
When yaw servo hydraulic switch is OFF, pedal forces should remain low due to yaw load compensator effect.
The Yaw Servo Hydraulic Check requires depressing the HYD TEST or ACCU TST button.
When HYD TEST or ACCU TST is depressed, forces should be felt on yaw pedals.
The Yaw Servo Hydraulic Check requires checking that the HYDR light flashes on the CWP.
The Yaw Servo Hydraulic Check requires turning the yaw servo hydraulic switch on collective grip to ON.

text:
# Hydraulic System Post-Test Examination

After the lower hydraulic system functional tests were performed, the hydraulic systems were visually examined for evidence of leaks; none were found. An unknown quantity of nitrogen pressure was lost from the yaw load compensator accumulator when a gauge was hooked up to the accumulator to measure the nitrogen charge; the nitrogen pressure measured about 7 bars. A normal accumulator charge is about 15 bars. The accumulator was re-pressurized with additional nitrogen until the gauge read 15 bars. The accumulator held the 15 bars of pressure, consistent with no significant leakage of nitrogen pressure from the accumulator. The hydraulic mule was powered on and the gauge, when attached to the accumulator, measured about 30 bars of pressure, consistent with the hydraulic pressure applied to the lower hydraulic circuit by the hydraulic mule. The hydraulic mule was subsequently powered off.

The hydraulic filter clogging indicator remained in the "in" position, consistent with the hydraulic filter not being clogged. The hydraulic filter element was removed and examined for debris; none was found on the filter element. However, very fine debris was observed in the bottom of the filter bowl.

The hydraulic pump drive belt from the lower hydraulic circuit was removed to verify engagement of the spline coupling connecting the drive pulley to the hydraulic pump. Spline coupling engagement was confirmed. The tail rotor pitch change links were disconnected from the tail rotor blades and the full range of pedal movement with corresponding movements of the pitch change was verified.

## The AS350B3 with the dual hydraulic system checklist requires a hydraulic system check during the helicopter run up. The checklist calls for the following:

1. Servo Distributors Seizure Check:
   a. [SERVO TEST] or [SERVO TST]  DEPRESS, SERVO light illuminates,
2. Yaw Servo Hydraulic Check:
   a. Yaw servo hydraulic switch (collective grip)  OFF, pedal forces should remain low (yaw load compensator effect).
   b. [HYD TEST] or [ACCU TST]  DEPRESS, check that forces are felt on yaw pedals.
   c. [CWP]: Check HYDR light flashes.
   d. Yaw servo hydraulic switch on collective grip; ON.
